values: Cause GDB to print structures in an indented format with one member per line.
Print the index of each element when displaying arrays.
Set the default base for numeric display.

Set a limit on how many elements of an array GDB will print.
Default is 200. 0 for unlimited.
Dumps a memory range to a file.

Print an expression.
Abbreviated p.
Use p/x for printing hexadecimal values.
Use * to dereference variables.
Append @[number] to print as an array of [number] elements.

(gdb) p i
$1 = 3

(gdb) p/x i
$2 = 0x3

(gdb) p arr
$3 = {0, 1, 2}

(gdb) p pArr
$4 = (int *) 0x7fffffffeb50

p *pArr@3
$5 = {0, 1, 2}

p *pArr
$6 = 0
Print all global and static variable names.
Print all local variables of current stack frame.
Print all local arguments of current stack frame.

(gdb) info args
str = 0x400674 "Sum of %d and %d"
param1 = 4
param2 = 3
Move to a specific frame from the backtrace to view locals or arguments.

(gdb) backtrace
#0  log (str=0x400674 "Sum of %d and %d", param1=4, param2=3) at main.c:13
#1  0x0000000000400584 in sum (a=4, b=3) at main.c:18
#2  0x00000000004005db in main () at main.c:34

(gdb) frame 2
#2  0x00000000004005db in main () at main.c:34 
34  s = sum(4, 3);

Make thread number ThreadNumber the current thread.
The command argument ThreadNumber is the internal gdb thread number, as shown in the first field of the 'info threads' display.

(gdb) info thread
  Id   Target Id         Frame
  2    Thread 0x7ffff77f5700 (LWP 27231) "a.out" myThreadFunc (vargp=0x0)
    at main.c:18
* 1    Thread 0x7ffff7fe7740 (LWP 27227) "a.out" 0x00007ffff7bc566b in pthread_join (threadid=140737345705728, thread_return=0x0) at pthread_join.c:92

(gdb) thread 2
[Switching to thread 2 (Thread 0x7ffff77f5700 (LWP 27231))]
#0  myThreadFunc (vargp=0x0) at main.c:18
18          while(1);

Print lines from a source file.
Abbreviated l.
Show current status of all threads in process.

(gdb) info thread
  Id   Target Id         Frame

    at main.c:18

[Switching to thread 2 (Thread 0x7ffff77f5700 (LWP 27231))]
#0  myThreadFunc (vargp=0x0) at main.c:18
18          while(1);

Set disassemmbly syntax to Intel style.

Continue to the next source line in the current (innermost) stack frame (step over).
Abbreviated n.

Execute one machine instruction, but if it is a function call, proceed until the function returns.
Abbreviated ni.

Execute one machine instruction, then stop and return to the debugger.
Abbreviated si.

Continue running your program until control reaches a different source line, then stop it and return control to GDB.
Abbreviated s.

Continue running until just after function in the selected stack frame returns. Print the returned value (if any).
Abbreviated fin.

(gdb) finish
Run till exit from #0  sum (a=4, b=3) at main.c:18
Sum of 4 and 3
0x00000000004005db in main () at main.c:34
34          s = sum(4, 3);
Value returned is $1 = 7

Set breakpoint.
Abbreviated b.
Use break <function> to set breakpoint using function name.
Use break *<address> to set breakpoint using address.

Start your program under GDB.

Examine memory.

n, f, and u are all optional parameters that specify how much memory to display and how to format it; addr is an expression giving the address where you want to start displaying memory. 

n, the repeat count:
    The repeat count is a decimal integer; the default is 1. It specifies how much memory (counting by units u) to display. 

f, the display format:
    The display format is one of the formats used by print (‘x’, ‘d’, ‘u’, ‘o’, ‘t’, ‘a’, ‘c’, ‘f’, ‘s’), and in addition ‘i’ (for machine instructions). 

u, the unit size:
    b for Bytes, h for Halfwords (two bytes), w for Words (four bytes), g for Giant words (eight bytes).

Analyse binary files for embeded files and executable code.

To extract embeded files from the original binary, use:
binwalk -e <binary>

$ binwalk foo.ico 

DECIMAL       HEXADECIMAL     DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
765           0x2FD           Zip archive data, at least v2.0 to extract, compressed size: 123, uncompressed size: 136, name: driver.txt
956           0x3BC           Zip archive data, at least v2.0 to extract, compressed size: 214, uncompressed size: 225, name: www.com
1392          0x570           End of Zip archive, footer length: 22

$ binwalk -e foo.ico 

DECIMAL       HEXADECIMAL     DESCRIPTION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
765           0x2FD           Zip archive data, at least v2.0 to extract, compressed size: 123, uncompressed size: 136, name: driver.txt
956           0x3BC           Zip archive data, at least v2.0 to extract, compressed size: 214, uncompressed size: 225, name: www.com
1392          0x570           End of Zip archive, footer length: 22

$ ls _foo.ico.extracted/
2FD.zip  driver.txt  www.com

Fetch documents/files from servers.

Useful flags:
-s, --silent: Silent mode, don't show progress meter or error messages.
-v, --verbose: Verbose mode.
-k, --insecure: Operate even for server connections otherwise considered insecure (don't check certificates).

$ curl http://www.example.com/ Example Domain

Display frames which contain a given string.
Export files from the HTTP layer.

Follow all streams using a tshark script:

See snippet in example.
$ END=$(tshark -r http.pcap -T fields -e tcp.stream | sort -n | tail -1); for ((i=0;i<=END;i++)); do echo $i; tshark -r http.pcap -qz follow,tcp,ascii,$i > follow-stream-$i.txt;done
Check the properties of executables (like PIE, RELRO, PaX, Canaries, ASLR, Fortify Source).

$ checksec.sh -f believeMe
RELRO           STACK CANARY      NX            PIE             RPATH      RUNPATH	Symbols		FORTIFY	Fortified	Fortifiable  FILE
Partial RELRO   Canary found      NX enabled    No PIE          No RPATH   No RUNPATH   82 Symbols	Yes	0		4	believeMe

Brute force directories and files in websites.

<extension> can be any extension (e.g. php, asp, txt) to append to common file names, or an astrix (*) for all extensions.

Use -w <dirlist> to use a prepared dir list (otherwise runs with default list).
Some lists can be found here:
https://github.com/diasdavid/node-dirbuster/tree/master/lists
